author: sky.cactus
content: If the person is interested in actually digging in or contributing to the research they should join us here.

author: butta
content: what are your thoughts regarding the charts?

author: sky.cactus
content: In my experience, the people who use Twitter are in it to gain followers, not to engage in productive discussion.  This is, of course, a very broad generalization but it is true often enough that I have given up on trying to debate with anyone on Twitter (and in fact, I no longer use Twitter at all, though for other reasons).

author: sky.cactus
content: My gut reaction is the same as it is every time you link one of these Twitter threads.  You can't say that "prices are up, thus EIP-1559 is bad".  Prices are up means demand is up, like we have reiterated here (and elsewhere) 100s of times.

author: butta
content: weak argument imo

author: butta
content: ‚Äûit‚Äôs not true because we cant know‚Äú

author: sky.cactus
content: The same cuts both ways.  You can't claim that "prices are up, it must be 1559".  We do not have a control group to compare against and there are *way* too many confounding variables.

author: sky.cactus
content: It would be *great* if we could know exactly what the market demand landscape for Ethereum block space was at all times.  EIP-1559 gives us *more* visibility into that but it still isn't perfect.

author: sky.cactus
content: Without knowing that, we cannot attribute any gas price increase to EIP-1559 or not.

author: sky.cactus
content: Also, this person makes the same mistake I see a lot of Twitter warriors making which is that they want Ethereum to optimize for their use case, not the use case of the general population.

author: sky.cactus
content: Many of us want Etherceum to be useful for *everyone*, not just day traders.  If you are a day trader, gas price estimation is *fun*.

author: sky.cactus
content: If you are a regular human, gas prices are a nightmare.  1559 does *not* help gas-price day traders, and in fact it arguably hurts them slightly because they can no longer leverage market inefficiencies for personal profit.

author: butta
content: the best we can do is compare pre and post,  and just saying it‚Äôs not true because we can‚Äòt know, doesn‚Äôt feel right to me.

author: sky.cactus
content: Doing so is worthless.

author: sky.cactus
content: You are comparing two different states of the universe that have billions of confounding differences.

author: sky.cactus
content:
"We found that fish don't survive in space, thus it must mean that microwave background radiation is terminal for fish."
... or they died from lack of water, lack of gravity, lack of pressure, extremely low effective temperatures, inability to shed heat, or any number of other things.

author: butta
content: you are bashing twitter but some comments are more helpful than your trollish input. https://twitter.com/pintail_xyz/status/1432293358723026946?s=21

author: sky.cactus
content: That won't address the OP's issues.

author: sky.cactus
content: In fact, it will arguably make them *worse* because prices will probably become more stable between blocks which means there are even fewer opportunities for sneaking in a low-ball transaction due to market inefficiencies.

author: Deleted User
content: imo this channel should be renamed to #fees because there kinda isnt a fee market anymore since EIP1559 introduced an algorithm that picks the price you pay. But thats nitpicking. But still seems important to be precise ?

author: sky.cactus
content: There is still a market, it just exports a single value result now.

author: sky.cactus
content: Similar to how you can have an open orderbook exchange and an output of that is the "mid-market price".

author: cf0009
content: We do know that demand is up: https://etherscan.io/chart/gasused

author: cf0009
content: I fully agree that Ethereum should be useful for everyone and I love the high demand. People want to use Ethereum, but the high gas prices and extremely limited throughput are capping the number of possible users

author: sky.cactus
content: They are capping the number of users today, so the entire system doesn't fall apart before we can make it sustainable.

author: sky.cactus
content: I want Ethereum to be around and useful in 10 years.  I'm willing to sacrifice throughput today in order to ensure that is the case.

author: sky.cactus
content: This is not a pump and dump for me.

author: Deleted User
content: Why not make it cheap for people who want pump and dump and expensive for people who wanna do the 10 year thing?

author: Deleted User
content: seems like the chain should reset every year but then you can pay a high fee if you want your stuff to carry over

author: sky.cactus
content: Regenesis and state expiry are both things in the works that will make it so we don't have to carry around state history forever, however neither are implemented at this time.

author: cf0009
content: All of this will take many years to come

author: sky.cactus
content: Potentially, yes.

author: cf0009
content: We all want that, but this is not just sacrificing throughput. Above all, it's sacrificing growth. Think of it like a bank deciding to charge high account fees. All the new people go to a new bank that offers free or cheap accounts, and they stay there for life. This can't be the policy cast in stone for years. There must be a middle ground. Supply must follow demand
